Expectation1: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation1: A familiar customer strolls in while the receptionist is free to chat.
Situation2: They prepare a sermon for Sunday service to guide the congregation in moral decisions.
Story: I was sweeping up hair clippings when Mrs. Lee, a regular, walked in, her face lighting up as she spotted me. The receptionist was free, but Mrs. Lee always preferred my chair, and I knew she expected a warm greeting and a listening ear. I smiled, setting aside my broom, but my mind was elsewhere—my half-finished sermon sat open on the back counter, waiting for inspiration. Sunday was approaching fast, and I still hadn’t found the right words to guide my congregation through a difficult moral dilemma. The weight of their expectations pressed on me; they looked to me for clarity and comfort, just as Mrs. Lee did now. I felt torn, caught between the gentle hum of the salon and the silent call of the pulpit, wondering how I could possibly be present for both.
